conclusion: Four objects are placed on a wooden surface, each casting a shadow due to a light source above them.
Shadows are formed because light cannot pass through opaque objects, and their size and shape depend on the relative positions of the light source, the object, and the surface.
When the light source moves closer to the objects (downward), it changes the angle of light rays hitting the objects.
As the light source gets closer, the angle between the light rays and the surface becomes steeper.
With the light source moving downward, the shadows will shift closer to the objects that cast them.
As the light source moves closer, the shadows become larger due to the light rays diverging more widely.
The shadow of Object A (Ice Cream Cone) will move closer to the ice cream cone and become larger.
The shadow of Object B (Typewriter) will move closer to the typewriter and increase in size.
The shadow of Object C (Sphere) will move closer to the sphere and grow bigger.
The shadow of Object D (Cylinder with Knife) will move closer to the cylinder and knife, and it will expand in size.
When the light source moves downward, shadows A, B, C, and D will all move closer to their respective objects and become larger.
